Query the GitHub API

Source: R/gh.R
gh.Rd

This is an extremely minimal client. You need to know the API to be able to use this client. All this function does is:

  • Try to substitute each listed parameter into endpoint, using the {parameter} notation.

  • If a GET request (the default), then add all other listed parameters as query parameters.

  • If not a GET request, then send the other parameters in the request body, as JSON.

  • Convert the response to an R list using jsonlite::fromJSON().

gh(
  endpoint,
  ...,
  per_page = NULL,
  .token = NULL,
  .destfile = NULL,
  .overwrite = FALSE,
  .api_url = NULL,
  .method = "GET",
  .limit = NULL,
  .accept = "application/vnd.github.v3+json",
  .send_headers = NULL,
  .progress = TRUE,
  .params = list()
)

Arguments

endpoint

GitHub API endpoint. Must be one of the following forms:

  • METHOD path, e.g. GET /rate_limit,

  • path, e.g. /rate_limit,

  • METHOD url, e.g. GET https://api.github.com/rate_limit,

  • url, e.g. https://api.github.com/rate_limit.

If the method is not supplied, will use .method, which defaults to "GET".
...

Name-value pairs giving API parameters. Will be matched into endpoint placeholders, sent as query parameters in GET requests, and as a JSON body of POST requests. If there is only one unnamed parameter, and it is a raw vector, then it will not be JSON encoded, but sent as raw data, as is. This can be used for example to add assets to releases. Named NULL values are silently dropped. For GET requests, named NA values trigger an error. For other methods, named NA values are included in the body of the request, as JSON null.
per_page

Number of items to return per page. If omitted, will be substituted by max(.limit, 100) if .limit is set, otherwise determined by the API (never greater than 100).
.token

Authentication token. Defaults to GITHUB_PAT or GITHUB_TOKEN environment variables, in this order if any is set. See gh_token() if you need more flexibility, e.g. different tokens for different GitHub Enterprise deployments.
.destfile

Path to write response to disk. If NULL (default), response will be processed and returned as an object. If path is given, response will be written to disk in the form sent.
.overwrite

If .destfile is provided, whether to overwrite an existing file. Defaults to FALSE.
.api_url

Github API url (default: https://api.github.com). Used if endpoint just contains a path. Defaults to GITHUB_API_URL environment variable if set.
.method

HTTP method to use if not explicitly supplied in the endpoint.
.limit

Number of records to return. This can be used instead of manual pagination. By default it is NULL, which means that the defaults of the GitHub API are used. You can set it to a number to request more (or less) records, and also to Inf to request all records. Note, that if you request many records, then multiple GitHub API calls are used to get them, and this can take a potentially long time.
.accept

The value of the Accept HTTP header. Defaults to "application/vnd.github.v3+json" . If Accept is given in .send_headers, then that will be used. This parameter can be used to provide a custom media type, in order to access a preview feature of the API.
.send_headers

Named character vector of header field values (except Authorization, which is handled via .token). This can be used to override or augment the default User-Agent header: "https://github.com/r-lib/gh".
.progress

Whether to show a progress indicator for calls that need more than one HTTP request.
.params

Additional list of parameters to append to .... It is easier to use this than ... if you have your parameters in a list already.

Value

Answer from the API as a gh_response object, which is also a list. Failed requests will generate an R error. Requests that generate a raw response will return a raw vector.

See also

gh_gql() if you want to use the GitHub GraphQL API, gh_whoami() for details on GitHub API token management.

Examples

## Repositories of a user, these are equivalent
gh("/users/hadley/repos", .limit = 2)

#>     "body": "This is essentially a repeat of #1004, as that one was closed. I want to add further motivation and a solution to the issue brought up there.\r\n\r\nFirst the motivation:\r\nSuppose we have a dataset containing NA values that we want to join to another dataset. These NA values might have a different meaning than missing data. Here's a real world example:\r\n```\r\nspeciesProperties=\r\n    tibble(\r\n        speciesId=1:3\r\n        ,scientificName=c(\"Recurvirostra avosetta\",\"Tadorna tadorna\",\"Larus ridibundus\")\r\n    )\r\ncountResults=\r\n    tibble(\r\n        speciesId=1:2\r\n        ,numberOfBirds=c(34,NA)\r\n    )\r\n```\r\nSuppose this is data from a bird census. Data for species 2 was lost. Species 3 was not encountered during the census. This is how bird census data is formatted in the real world, as there are thousands of bird species on this planet and not having to note species that don't occur saves a lot of work.\r\n\r\nIn this case I'd like to join the tables with this syntax:\r\n```\r\nspeciesProperties %>% \r\n    left_join(\r\n        countResults\r\n        ,missing=c(numberOfBirds=0) # this function parameter does not exist, i suggest adding it.\r\n    )\r\n```\r\nAnd the expected result would be:\r\n```\r\n# A tibble: 3 x 3\r\n  speciesId scientificName         numberOfBirds\r\n      <int> <chr>                  <chr>        \r\n1         1 Recurvirostra avosetta 34            \r\n2         2 Tadorna tadorna        NA           \r\n3         3 Larus ridibundus       0            \r\n```\r\nNote how species 2 is treated differently from species 3.\r\nThe current version of joins doesn't allow for this differentiation, resulting in a loss of data:\r\n```\r\n# A tibble: 3 x 3\r\n  speciesId scientificName         numberOfBirds\r\n      <int> <chr>                  <chr>        \r\n1         1 Recurvirostra avosetta 34            \r\n2         2 Tadorna tadorna        NA           \r\n3         3 Larus ridibundus       NA           \r\n```\r\nThe \"simplest\" workaround that I found with the current version of joins is the following one. It should be noted that in this special case I could have simplified the code by temporarily recoding NA as -1, as bird counts can never be negative. I decided to show the more complicated general solution using an auxilliary variable, however, as this feature request is supposed to be of general use.\r\n```\r\nspeciesProperties %>% \r\n    left_join(\r\n        countResults %>% \r\n            mutate(nBirdsMissing=is.na(numberOfBirds))\r\n    ) %>% \r\n    mutate(\r\n        numberOfBirds=\r\n            ifelse(\r\n                !nBirdsMissing|is.na(nBirdsMissing)\r\n                ,ifelse(\r\n                    is.na(numberOfBirds),0,numberOfBirds\r\n                )\r\n                ,NA\r\n            )\r\n    ) %>% \r\n    select(-nBirdsMissing)\r\n```\r\nMaybe there is a still simpler workaround, but I couldn't find one. Even if there is a simpler workaround however, the fact that it (apparently) is hard to come up with one suggests that the feature request has merit. This issue has come up many times for me during practical data analysis.\r\n\r\nIn the original #1004 it was brought up that different variable types (e.g. numeric, character, date, factor, ...) would require different filler values, so one would need to specify a value for each possible variable type. I suggest instead defining it on a per column basis, as each column can only have one variable type (which may be \"list\"). I've shown how this could look like in the example above (2nd codeblock), using a named vector where the name of the vector elements corresponds to the column names.",

#>     "body": "`lag` and `lead` currently mandate that the lag value `n` be a length-1 integer value. Is there a specific reason for this?\r\n\r\nI was able to write the following function which allows for length-X vectors in `n`:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nmyLag <- function(x, n = 1, default = NA) {\r\n    i <- pmax(seq_along(x) - n, 0)\r\n    x <- c(default, x)\r\n    x[i + 1]\r\n}\r\n\r\nmyLag(10:15)\r\n#> [1] NA 10 11 12 13 14\r\nmyLag(10:15, 0:5)\r\n#> [1] 10 10 10 10 10 10\r\nmyLag(10:15, 5:0)\r\n#> [1] NA NA NA 11 13 15\r\nmyLag(10:15, 1:2)\r\n#> [1] NA NA 11 11 13 13\r\nmyLag(10:15, 2:1)\r\n#> [1] NA 10 10 12 12 14\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2021-10-11 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.1)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nObviously, it lacks some of the checks in `dplyr::lag`, but those would be straightforward to include. It also doesn't include the `order_by` argument and implementation, but at a glance that also seems to be a simple drop-in.\r\n\r\nWith this implementation, if `x`'s length is not a multiple of `n`'s, a warning is thrown and the output is usually not what was expected, but that could be handled by the standard dplyr error of `\"n must be of length {length(x)} or 1, not {length(n)}\"` (though that'd make some of the examples above not work, but I'm fine with that).\r\n\r\nBut most importantly, is there a reason why `lag` currently requires `n` to be length-1?",

#>     "body": "Most databases support the `RETURNING` clause after an INSERT action. It returns all the inserted rows. When working with databases this is useful for two reasons:\r\n\r\n1. Knowing which subset of the new data was actually inserted.\r\n2. To add the ID (or other columns) to your local data (and avoid an extra roundtrip to the database)\r\n\r\nExample for 2: you have an address book database table with columns (`id`, `surname`, `name`) and a local data frame of people (`surname`, `name`). Now you want to add the `id` to your local data frame. If all people are already in the database table then it's an easy join. But let's assume that Davis is still missing. Then you could do something like\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# in the beginning only Hadley is in our address book\r\ntbl(con, \"addressbook\") %>% collect()\r\n# # A tibble: 1 × 3\r\n#      id surname name   \r\n#   <int> <chr>   <chr>  \r\n# 1     1 Hadley  Wickham\r\n\r\n# we now want to get the `id` for two people\r\nrows_insert(\r\n  tbl(con, \"addressbook\"),\r\n  tibble(\r\n    surname = c(\"Hadley\", \"Davis\"),\r\n    name = c(\"Wickham\", \"Vaughan\")\r\n  ),\r\n  returning = everything()\r\n) %>% \r\n  get_returned_rows()\r\n\r\n# Davis was added to our address book and we get the `id` for both\r\n# the `id` column \r\n# # A tibble: 2 × 3\r\n#      id surname name   \r\n#   <int> <chr>   <chr>  \r\n# 1     1 Hadley  Wickham\r\n# 2     2 Davis   Vaughan\r\n```\r\n\r\nSimilarly, `RETURNING` exists for `UPDATE` and `DELETE`.\r\nSo, for databases using `RETURNING` is pretty common. For local dataframes it might make sense to also support this when e.g. `rows_patch()` doesn't require all keys in `y` to exist in `x` (see [issue](https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/5984)). With `returning` you would then know which rows in your original dataframe were modified.\r\n\r\nI'm currently working on [supporting the SQL returning clause](https://github.com/cynkra/dm/pull/607) in `dm::rows_insert.tbl_dbi()` and friends. It would probably be nice if `returning` would support tidyselect. Unfortunately, when using tidyselect syntax we get a warning about an argument of the dots not being used. This is because the generic `rows_insert()` has the check `ellipsis::check_dots_used()`. This warning cannot be avoided because we need to `enquo()` the `returning` argument and cannot force the evaluation of it.\r\n\r\nTo summarise:\r\n-> supporting `returning` for local dataframes might make sense\r\n-> if you agree that `returning` makes sense for database tables and it should allow tidyselect then `returning` should be added as an argument to the generic",

#>     "body": "I tried to use `row_patch` to fill in missing values in a data frame.  It failed by design, because it didn't meet the requirement for the function: \"key values in y must occur in x\".  However, I was able to successfully execute the row patch by using the `match` function from base R (see below).  \r\n\r\nThis isn't a typical bug report because it is clearly stated that this is a limitation of the function, but I wanted to point out that it can be done using a different function from base R.  Since `row_patch` is currently an experimental function in `dplyr`, I wanted to provide feedback to hopefully improve it.  `row_patch` is much cleaner and I would prefer to use it if possible.\r\n\r\nIt would also be nice if `row_patch` could preserve other variables in y that don't occur in x.  `match` can handle this as well.\r\n\r\n```r\r\nD1 <- data.frame(\r\n  id=seq(1,3),\r\n  x=c(\"cow\",NA,\"sheep\"))\r\n\r\nD2 <- data.frame(\r\n  id=seq(1,4),\r\n  x=c(\"cow\",\"turtle\",\"parrot\",\"frog\"))\r\n\r\n#rows_patch fails\r\nD1 %>%\r\n  rows_patch(D2, by = \"id\")\r\n\r\n#match works\r\nna <- is.na(D1$x)\r\n\r\nD1$x[na] <- D2$x[match(D1$id[na],D2$id)]\r\n```\r\n",

This does not require stringi.\r\n\r\n`dplyr_locale()` is a new exported helper and returns a string representing the default locale to use. It has the following properties:\r\n- If stringi is installed, use `\"en\"`.\r\n- If stringi is not installed, use `\"C\"` with a warning. #>     "body": "One thing I often do in production code after a merge is validating my assumptions on unique keys and relationship between them in both merge inputs (i.e. [cardinality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cardinality_%28data_modeling%29) checks). For example, if I have duplicated keys in one data frame and perform an inner join, I end up with more rows that both input tables had, which might come as a surprise and can cause downstream problems if I don't manually assert this. \r\n\r\nIn a script, checking these conditions and raising a (helpful) error can take a few lines of code quickly, let alone the verbosity if you have multiple sequential joins. For that reason, I propose to offer the user the option to opt in for cardinality validation as part of the join, very much like Python's [pandas implemented this](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.merge.html):\r\n\r\n```python\r\nimport pandas\r\npandas.merge(..., validate = 'one_to_one')\r\n```\r\n\r\nIn {dplyr}, it could be\r\n\r\n```r\r\ndplyr::inner_join(..., validate = \"1:N\")\r\n```\r\n\r\nMaybe we could the official abbreviations (not sure they even exist, maybe case insensitive), e.g. `1:n`, `m:n` etc.\r\n\r\nIf this is out of scope for {dplyr}, maybe it's something for @krlmlr in {dm}?",

#>     "body": "Closes #5914 \r\nCloses #5661 \r\nCloses #5413 \r\nCloses #2240 (a whopping 5 years old! with 138 thumbs up!)\r\n\r\n# Reading order\r\n\r\n- NEWS\r\n\r\n- `join-by.R`\r\n   - To read `join_by()` docs / examples and to get a general idea of how it works\r\n   - I've tried to error intelligently for many bad user inputs in the parsing code. This probably doesn't need quite as deep of a review.\r\n\r\n- `join.R` \r\n   - To read updated docs\r\n   - Note that all joins go through `join_rows()` now\r\n\r\n- `join-rows.R`\r\n   - This basically remaps dplyr arguments to `vec_matches()` arguments and calls `vec_matches()`\r\n   - Many errors are rethrown from vctrs with more applicable error messages\r\n\r\n- `join-cols.R`\r\n   - To see how `keep = NULL` is handled\r\n   - `standardise_join_by()` was replaced by `as_join_by()` and `join_by_common()` in `join-by.R`\r\n\r\n- Tests\r\n   - I've added quite a few for the `join_by()` parsing checks\r\n   - I've also added snapshot tests for the rethrown errors from `dplyr_matches()`\r\n   - It's worth noting that a number of tests needed an explicit `multiple = \"all\"` now to silence the new warning\r\n\r\n# Summary\r\n\r\nThis PR implements has two main purposes:\r\n\r\n1. It adds `join_by()` for creating a _join specification_ which can be specified as the `by` argument to any join. This allows:\r\n    - Equi join specification with unnamed left and right hand sides, i.e. `join_by(date1 == date2)`\r\n \r\n    - Specification of non-equi joins like `join_by(id, date1 >= date2)`\r\n\r\n    - Specification of rolling joins with `join_by(id, preceding(date1, date2))` and `join_by(id, following(date1, date2))`\r\n    \r\n    - Shortcuts for some complex non-equi joins: `between()`, `overlaps()`, `within()`. \r\n\r\n    - There is a restriction that the left and right hand side of the join conditions have to be symbols or strings, i.e. you can't do `join_by(x + 1 > y)`. It is unclear what the resulting column name should be if you did this, and you can get into order of operation issues, i.e. `!x > y` where `!` has a higher precedence than `>`.\r\n\r\n    - To support non-equi joins, `keep` has gain a completely new default value of `NULL`. In non-equi joins like `join_by(sale_date >= commercial_date)`, since the information in the two columns isn't exactly the same, you almost always want to keep both columns. So `keep = NULL` implies `keep = FALSE` for equi conditions and `keep = TRUE` for non-equi conditions. This should be fully backwards compatible.\r\n\r\n2. It adds two new \"quality control\" arguments to most of the join functions that have been requested over the years.\r\n    - `multiple` is a new argument for controlling what happens when a row in `x` matches multiple rows in `y`. It allows `c(\"all\", \"first\", \"last\", \"warning\", \"error\")`. The default is `NULL`, which uses `\"warning\"` for equi and rolling joins, where multiple matches are surprising, and `\"all\"` for cross joins and when there is at least 1 non-equi join condition, where multiple matches are expected. This is a change from the current CRAN dplyr behavior, which never warns.\r\n\r\n    - `unmatched` is a new argument for controlling what happens when a row would be dropped because it doesn't have a match. It allows `c(\"drop\", \"error\")`.\r\n\r\n    - Combined with the proposed `enforce()`, this allows for a number of useful checks to ensure that you are doing a 1:1, 1:m, m:1, m:m style join.\r\n\r\n# Not implemented\r\n\r\nFuture enhancements for other PRs (as suggested from comments):\r\n- `join_any()` that would accept arbitrary predicates and would perform a much slower cartesian join + filter using the predicates. It could do it in batches to reduce peak memory. This would require a completely separate engine path for each type of join.\r\n\r\n- `join_at()` a tidy select interface for equi joins if you have many columns of the same name to join by. This would have an `as_join_by()` method that translated the result to a `dplyr_join_by` object.\r\n\r\n# Examples\r\n\r\n<details>\r\n \r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n\r\nset.seed(123)\r\ndates <- as.Date(\"2019-01-01\") + 0:4\r\nneedles <- tibble(dates = dates, x = sample(length(dates)))\r\n\r\nset.seed(123)\r\nlower <- as.Date(\"2019-01-01\") + sample(6, 5, replace = TRUE)\r\nupper <- lower + sample(2, 5, replace = TRUE)\r\nhaystack <- tibble(lower = lower, upper = upper, y = sample(length(lower)))\r\n\r\nneedles\r\n#> # A tibble: 5 x 2\r\n#>   dates          x\r\n#>   <date>     <int>\r\n#> 1 2019-01-01     3\r\n#> 2 2019-01-02     2\r\n#> 3 2019-01-03     5\r\n#> 4 2019-01-04     4\r\n#> 5 2019-01-05     1\r\nhaystack\r\n#> # A tibble: 5 x 3\r\n#>   lower      upper          y\r\n#>   <date>     <date>     <int>\r\n#> 1 2019-01-04 2019-01-06     1\r\n#> 2 2019-01-07 2019-01-08     2\r\n#> 3 2019-01-04 2019-01-05     3\r\n#> 4 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     4\r\n#> 5 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     5\r\n\r\n# Non-equi join\r\n# For each row in `needles`, find locations in `haystack` matching the condition\r\nleft_join(needles, haystack, by = join_by(dates >= lower, dates <= upper))\r\n#> # A tibble: 12 x 5\r\n#>    dates          x lower      upper          y\r\n#>    <date>     <int> <date>     <date>     <int>\r\n#>  1 2019-01-01     3 NA         NA            NA\r\n#>  2 2019-01-02     2 NA         NA            NA\r\n#>  3 2019-01-03     5 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     4\r\n#>  4 2019-01-03     5 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     5\r\n#>  5 2019-01-04     4 2019-01-04 2019-01-06     1\r\n#>  6 2019-01-04     4 2019-01-04 2019-01-05     3\r\n#>  7 2019-01-04     4 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     4\r\n#>  8 2019-01-04     4 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     5\r\n#>  9 2019-01-05     1 2019-01-04 2019-01-06     1\r\n#> 10 2019-01-05     1 2019-01-04 2019-01-05     3\r\n#> 11 2019-01-05     1 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     4\r\n#> 12 2019-01-05     1 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     5\r\n\r\n# If we really cared about including row 2 from `haystack` that wasn't matched by `needles`...\r\nfull_join(needles, haystack, by = join_by(dates >= lower, dates <= upper))\r\n#> # #>     "body": "This is essentially a repeat of #1004, as that one was closed. I want to add further motivation and a solution to the issue brought up there.\r\n\r\nFirst the motivation:\r\nSuppose we have a dataset containing NA values that we want to join to another dataset. These NA values might have a different meaning than missing data. Here's a real world example:\r\n```\r\nspeciesProperties=\r\n    tibble(\r\n        speciesId=1:3\r\n        ,scientificName=c(\"Recurvirostra avosetta\",\"Tadorna tadorna\",\"Larus ridibundus\")\r\n    )\r\ncountResults=\r\n    tibble(\r\n        speciesId=1:2\r\n        ,numberOfBirds=c(34,NA)\r\n    )\r\n```\r\nSuppose this is data from a bird census. Data for species 2 was lost. Species 3 was not encountered during the census. This is how bird census data is formatted in the real world, as there are thousands of bird species on this planet and not having to note species that don't occur saves a lot of work.\r\n\r\nIn this case I'd like to join the tables with this syntax:\r\n```\r\nspeciesProperties %>% \r\n    left_join(\r\n        countResults\r\n        ,missing=c(numberOfBirds=0) # this function parameter does not exist, i suggest adding it.\r\n    )\r\n```\r\nAnd the expected result would be:\r\n```\r\n# A tibble: 3 x 3\r\n  speciesId scientificName         numberOfBirds\r\n      <int> <chr>                  <chr>        \r\n1         1 Recurvirostra avosetta 34            \r\n2         2 Tadorna tadorna        NA           \r\n3         3 Larus ridibundus       0            \r\n```\r\nNote how species 2 is treated differently from species 3.\r\nThe current version of joins doesn't allow for this differentiation, resulting in a loss of data:\r\n```\r\n# A tibble: 3 x 3\r\n  speciesId scientificName         numberOfBirds\r\n      <int> <chr>                  <chr>        \r\n1         1 Recurvirostra avosetta 34            \r\n2         2 Tadorna tadorna        NA           \r\n3         3 Larus ridibundus       NA           \r\n```\r\nThe \"simplest\" workaround that I found with the current version of joins is the following one. It should be noted that in this special case I could have simplified the code by temporarily recoding NA as -1, as bird counts can never be negative. I decided to show the more complicated general solution using an auxilliary variable, however, as this feature request is supposed to be of general use.\r\n```\r\nspeciesProperties %>% \r\n    left_join(\r\n        countResults %>% \r\n            mutate(nBirdsMissing=is.na(numberOfBirds))\r\n    ) %>% \r\n    mutate(\r\n        numberOfBirds=\r\n            ifelse(\r\n                !nBirdsMissing|is.na(nBirdsMissing)\r\n                ,ifelse(\r\n                    is.na(numberOfBirds),0,numberOfBirds\r\n                )\r\n                ,NA\r\n            )\r\n    ) %>% \r\n    select(-nBirdsMissing)\r\n```\r\nMaybe there is a still simpler workaround, but I couldn't find one. Even if there is a simpler workaround however, the fact that it (apparently) is hard to come up with one suggests that the feature request has merit. This issue has come up many times for me during practical data analysis.\r\n\r\nIn the original #1004 it was brought up that different variable types (e.g. numeric, character, date, factor, ...) would require different filler values, so one would need to specify a value for each possible variable type. I suggest instead defining it on a per column basis, as each column can only have one variable type (which may be \"list\"). I've shown how this could look like in the example above (2nd codeblock), using a named vector where the name of the vector elements corresponds to the column names.",

#>     "body": "`lag` and `lead` currently mandate that the lag value `n` be a length-1 integer value. Is there a specific reason for this?\r\n\r\nI was able to write the following function which allows for length-X vectors in `n`:\r\n\r\n``` r\r\nmyLag <- function(x, n = 1, default = NA) {\r\n    i <- pmax(seq_along(x) - n, 0)\r\n    x <- c(default, x)\r\n    x[i + 1]\r\n}\r\n\r\nmyLag(10:15)\r\n#> [1] NA 10 11 12 13 14\r\nmyLag(10:15, 0:5)\r\n#> [1] 10 10 10 10 10 10\r\nmyLag(10:15, 5:0)\r\n#> [1] NA NA NA 11 13 15\r\nmyLag(10:15, 1:2)\r\n#> [1] NA NA 11 11 13 13\r\nmyLag(10:15, 2:1)\r\n#> [1] NA 10 10 12 12 14\r\n```\r\n\r\n<sup>Created on 2021-10-11 by the [reprex package](https://reprex.tidyverse.org) (v2.0.1)<\/sup>\r\n\r\nObviously, it lacks some of the checks in `dplyr::lag`, but those would be straightforward to include. It also doesn't include the `order_by` argument and implementation, but at a glance that also seems to be a simple drop-in.\r\n\r\nWith this implementation, if `x`'s length is not a multiple of `n`'s, a warning is thrown and the output is usually not what was expected, but that could be handled by the standard dplyr error of `\"n must be of length {length(x)} or 1, not {length(n)}\"` (though that'd make some of the examples above not work, but I'm fine with that).\r\n\r\nBut most importantly, is there a reason why `lag` currently requires `n` to be length-1?",

#>     "body": "Most databases support the `RETURNING` clause after an INSERT action. It returns all the inserted rows. When working with databases this is useful for two reasons:\r\n\r\n1. Knowing which subset of the new data was actually inserted.\r\n2. To add the ID (or other columns) to your local data (and avoid an extra roundtrip to the database)\r\n\r\nExample for 2: you have an address book database table with columns (`id`, `surname`, `name`) and a local data frame of people (`surname`, `name`). Now you want to add the `id` to your local data frame. If all people are already in the database table then it's an easy join. But let's assume that Davis is still missing. Then you could do something like\r\n\r\n```r\r\n# in the beginning only Hadley is in our address book\r\ntbl(con, \"addressbook\") %>% collect()\r\n# # A tibble: 1 × 3\r\n#      id surname name   \r\n#   <int> <chr>   <chr>  \r\n# 1     1 Hadley  Wickham\r\n\r\n# we now want to get the `id` for two people\r\nrows_insert(\r\n  tbl(con, \"addressbook\"),\r\n  tibble(\r\n    surname = c(\"Hadley\", \"Davis\"),\r\n    name = c(\"Wickham\", \"Vaughan\")\r\n  ),\r\n  returning = everything()\r\n) %>% \r\n  get_returned_rows()\r\n\r\n# Davis was added to our address book and we get the `id` for both\r\n# the `id` column \r\n# # A tibble: 2 × 3\r\n#      id surname name   \r\n#   <int> <chr>   <chr>  \r\n# 1     1 Hadley  Wickham\r\n# 2     2 Davis   Vaughan\r\n```\r\n\r\nSimilarly, `RETURNING` exists for `UPDATE` and `DELETE`.\r\nSo, for databases using `RETURNING` is pretty common. For local dataframes it might make sense to also support this when e.g. `rows_patch()` doesn't require all keys in `y` to exist in `x` (see [issue](https://github.com/tidyverse/dplyr/issues/5984)). With `returning` you would then know which rows in your original dataframe were modified.\r\n\r\nI'm currently working on [supporting the SQL returning clause](https://github.com/cynkra/dm/pull/607) in `dm::rows_insert.tbl_dbi()` and friends. It would probably be nice if `returning` would support tidyselect. Unfortunately, when using tidyselect syntax we get a warning about an argument of the dots not being used. This is because the generic `rows_insert()` has the check `ellipsis::check_dots_used()`. This warning cannot be avoided because we need to `enquo()` the `returning` argument and cannot force the evaluation of it.\r\n\r\nTo summarise:\r\n-> supporting `returning` for local dataframes might make sense\r\n-> if you agree that `returning` makes sense for database tables and it should allow tidyselect then `returning` should be added as an argument to the generic",

#>     "body": "I tried to use `row_patch` to fill in missing values in a data frame.  It failed by design, because it didn't meet the requirement for the function: \"key values in y must occur in x\".  However, I was able to successfully execute the row patch by using the `match` function from base R (see below).  \r\n\r\nThis isn't a typical bug report because it is clearly stated that this is a limitation of the function, but I wanted to point out that it can be done using a different function from base R.  Since `row_patch` is currently an experimental function in `dplyr`, I wanted to provide feedback to hopefully improve it.  `row_patch` is much cleaner and I would prefer to use it if possible.\r\n\r\nIt would also be nice if `row_patch` could preserve other variables in y that don't occur in x.  `match` can handle this as well.\r\n\r\n```r\r\nD1 <- data.frame(\r\n  id=seq(1,3),\r\n  x=c(\"cow\",NA,\"sheep\"))\r\n\r\nD2 <- data.frame(\r\n  id=seq(1,4),\r\n  x=c(\"cow\",\"turtle\",\"parrot\",\"frog\"))\r\n\r\n#rows_patch fails\r\nD1 %>%\r\n  rows_patch(D2, by = \"id\")\r\n\r\n#match works\r\nna <- is.na(D1$x)\r\n\r\nD1$x[na] <- D2$x[match(D1$id[na],D2$id)]\r\n```\r\n",

#>     "body": "Supersedes #5868 (as this is a cleaner git history)\r\nCloses #4962\r\nCloses #5090\r\nPart of #5808\r\n\r\nRequires dev vctrs.\r\n\r\nThis PR adds a `.locale` argument to `arrange()`, with 3 possible options:\r\n- `dplyr_locale()`, the default. See below.\r\n- A single stringi locale identifier, like `\"en_US\"` or `\"fr\"`. This requires stringi.\r\n- `\"C\"`, for sorting in the C locale. This does not require stringi.\r\n\r\n`dplyr_locale()` is a new exported helper and returns a string representing the default locale to use. It has the following properties:\r\n- If stringi is installed, use `\"en\"`.\r\n- If stringi is not installed, use `\"C\"` with a warning. The warning can be silenced by installing stringi or specifying `.locale = \"C\"` explicitly.\r\n- If the `dplyr.locale` option is set to a stringi locale identifier or `\"C\"`, that overrides the above default behavior.\r\n\r\nThis is a breaking change, as we no longer respect the `LC_COLLATE` option.",

#>     "body": "One thing I often do in production code after a merge is validating my assumptions on unique keys and relationship between them in both merge inputs (i.e. [cardinality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cardinality_%28data_modeling%29) checks). For example, if I have duplicated keys in one data frame and perform an inner join, I end up with more rows that both input tables had, which might come as a surprise and can cause downstream problems if I don't manually assert this. \r\n\r\nIn a script, checking these conditions and raising a (helpful) error can take a few lines of code quickly, let alone the verbosity if you have multiple sequential joins. For that reason, I propose to offer the user the option to opt in for cardinality validation as part of the join, very much like Python's [pandas implemented this](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.merge.html):\r\n\r\n```python\r\nimport pandas\r\npandas.merge(..., validate = 'one_to_one')\r\n```\r\n\r\nIn {dplyr}, it could be\r\n\r\n```r\r\ndplyr::inner_join(..., validate = \"1:N\")\r\n```\r\n\r\nMaybe we could the official abbreviations (not sure they even exist, maybe case insensitive), e.g. `1:n`, `m:n` etc.\r\n\r\nIf this is out of scope for {dplyr}, maybe it's something for @krlmlr in {dm}?",

#>     "body": "Closes #5914 \r\nCloses #5661 \r\nCloses #5413 \r\nCloses #2240 (a whopping 5 years old! with 138 thumbs up!)\r\n\r\n# Reading order\r\n\r\n- NEWS\r\n\r\n- `join-by.R`\r\n   - To read `join_by()` docs / examples and to get a general idea of how it works\r\n   - I've tried to error intelligently for many bad user inputs in the parsing code. This probably doesn't need quite as deep of a review.\r\n\r\n- `join.R` \r\n   - To read updated docs\r\n   - Note that all joins go through `join_rows()` now\r\n\r\n- `join-rows.R`\r\n   - This basically remaps dplyr arguments to `vec_matches()` arguments and calls `vec_matches()`\r\n   - Many errors are rethrown from vctrs with more applicable error messages\r\n\r\n- `join-cols.R`\r\n   - To see how `keep = NULL` is handled\r\n   - `standardise_join_by()` was replaced by `as_join_by()` and `join_by_common()` in `join-by.R`\r\n\r\n- Tests\r\n   - I've added quite a few for the `join_by()` parsing checks\r\n   - I've also added snapshot tests for the rethrown errors from `dplyr_matches()`\r\n   - It's worth noting that a number of tests needed an explicit `multiple = \"all\"` now to silence the new warning\r\n\r\n# Summary\r\n\r\nThis PR implements has two main purposes:\r\n\r\n1. It adds `join_by()` for creating a _join specification_ which can be specified as the `by` argument to any join. This allows:\r\n    - Equi join specification with unnamed left and right hand sides, i.e. `join_by(date1 == date2)`\r\n \r\n    - Specification of non-equi joins like `join_by(id, date1 >= date2)`\r\n\r\n    - Specification of rolling joins with `join_by(id, preceding(date1, date2))` and `join_by(id, following(date1, date2))`\r\n    \r\n    - Shortcuts for some complex non-equi joins: `between()`, `overlaps()`, `within()`. \r\n\r\n    - There is a restriction that the left and right hand side of the join conditions have to be symbols or strings, i.e. you can't do `join_by(x + 1 > y)`. It is unclear what the resulting column name should be if you did this, and you can get into order of operation issues, i.e. `!x > y` where `!` has a higher precedence than `>`.\r\n\r\n    - To support non-equi joins, `keep` has gain a completely new default value of `NULL`. In non-equi joins like `join_by(sale_date >= commercial_date)`, since the information in the two columns isn't exactly the same, you almost always want to keep both columns. So `keep = NULL` implies `keep = FALSE` for equi conditions and `keep = TRUE` for non-equi conditions. This should be fully backwards compatible.\r\n\r\n2. It adds two new \"quality control\" arguments to most of the join functions that have been requested over the years.\r\n    - `multiple` is a new argument for controlling what happens when a row in `x` matches multiple rows in `y`. It allows `c(\"all\", \"first\", \"last\", \"warning\", \"error\")`. The default is `NULL`, which uses `\"warning\"` for equi and rolling joins, where multiple matches are surprising, and `\"all\"` for cross joins and when there is at least 1 non-equi join condition, where multiple matches are expected. This is a change from the current CRAN dplyr behavior, which never warns.\r\n\r\n    - `unmatched` is a new argument for controlling what happens when a row would be dropped because it doesn't have a match. It allows `c(\"drop\", \"error\")`.\r\n\r\n    - Combined with the proposed `enforce()`, this allows for a number of useful checks to ensure that you are doing a 1:1, 1:m, m:1, m:m style join.\r\n\r\n# Not implemented\r\n\r\nFuture enhancements for other PRs (as suggested from comments):\r\n- `join_any()` that would accept arbitrary predicates and would perform a much slower cartesian join + filter using the predicates. It could do it in batches to reduce peak memory. This would require a completely separate engine path for each type of join.\r\n\r\n- `join_at()` a tidy select interface for equi joins if you have many columns of the same name to join by. This would have an `as_join_by()` method that translated the result to a `dplyr_join_by` object.\r\n\r\n# Examples\r\n\r\n<details>\r\n \r\n``` r\r\nlibrary(dplyr)\r\n\r\nset.seed(123)\r\ndates <- as.Date(\"2019-01-01\") + 0:4\r\nneedles <- tibble(dates = dates, x = sample(length(dates)))\r\n\r\nset.seed(123)\r\nlower <- as.Date(\"2019-01-01\") + sample(6, 5, replace = TRUE)\r\nupper <- lower + sample(2, 5, replace = TRUE)\r\nhaystack <- tibble(lower = lower, upper = upper, y = sample(length(lower)))\r\n\r\nneedles\r\n#> # A tibble: 5 x 2\r\n#>   dates          x\r\n#>   <date>     <int>\r\n#> 1 2019-01-01     3\r\n#> 2 2019-01-02     2\r\n#> 3 2019-01-03     5\r\n#> 4 2019-01-04     4\r\n#> 5 2019-01-05     1\r\nhaystack\r\n#> # A tibble: 5 x 3\r\n#>   lower      upper          y\r\n#>   <date>     <date>     <int>\r\n#> 1 2019-01-04 2019-01-06     1\r\n#> 2 2019-01-07 2019-01-08     2\r\n#> 3 2019-01-04 2019-01-05     3\r\n#> 4 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     4\r\n#> 5 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     5\r\n\r\n# Non-equi join\r\n# For each row in `needles`, find locations in `haystack` matching the condition\r\nleft_join(needles, haystack, by = join_by(dates >= lower, dates <= upper))\r\n#> # A tibble: 12 x 5\r\n#>    dates          x lower      upper          y\r\n#>    <date>     <int> <date>     <date>     <int>\r\n#>  1 2019-01-01     3 NA         NA            NA\r\n#>  2 2019-01-02     2 NA         NA            NA\r\n#>  3 2019-01-03     5 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     4\r\n#>  4 2019-01-03     5 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     5\r\n#>  5 2019-01-04     4 2019-01-04 2019-01-06     1\r\n#>  6 2019-01-04     4 2019-01-04 2019-01-05     3\r\n#>  7 2019-01-04     4 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     4\r\n#>  8 2019-01-04     4 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     5\r\n#>  9 2019-01-05     1 2019-01-04 2019-01-06     1\r\n#> 10 2019-01-05     1 2019-01-04 2019-01-05     3\r\n#> 11 2019-01-05     1 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     4\r\n#> 12 2019-01-05     1 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     5\r\n\r\n# If we really cared about including row 2 from `haystack` that wasn't matched by `needles`...\r\nfull_join(needles, haystack, by = join_by(dates >= lower, dates <= upper))\r\n#> # A tibble: 13 x 5\r\n#>    dates          x lower      upper          y\r\n#>    <date>     <int> <date>     <date>     <int>\r\n#>  1 2019-01-01     3 NA         NA            NA\r\n#>  2 2019-01-02     2 NA         NA            NA\r\n#>  3 2019-01-03     5 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     4\r\n#>  4 2019-01-03     5 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     5\r\n#>  5 2019-01-04     4 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     4\r\n#>  6 2019-01-04     4 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     5\r\n#>  7 2019-01-04     4 2019-01-04 2019-01-05     3\r\n#>  8 2019-01-04     4 2019-01-04 2019-01-06     1\r\n#>  9 2019-01-05     1 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     4\r\n#> 10 2019-01-05     1 2019-01-03 2019-01-05     5\r\n#> 11 2019-01-05     1 2019-01-04 2019-01-05     3\r\n#> 12 2019-01-05     1 2019-01-04 2019-01-06     1\r\n#> 13 NA            NA 2019-01-07 2019-01-08     2\r\n\r\n\r\nsales <- tibble(\r\n  sale_id = c(\"S0\", \"S1\", \"S2\", \"S3\", \"S4\", \"S5\"),\r\n  sale_date = as.Date(c(\"2013-2-20\", \"2014-5-1\", \"2014-5-1\", \"2014-6-15\", \"2014-7-1\", \"2014-12-31\"))\r\n)\r\ncommercials <- tibble(\r\n  comm_id = c(\"C1\", \"C2\", \"C3\", \"C4\", \"C5\"),\r\n  comm_date = as.Date(c(\"2014-1-1\", \"2014-4-1\", \"2014-7-1\", \"2014-9-15\", \"2014-9-15\"))\r\n)\r\n\r\nsales\r\n#> # A tibble: 6 x 2\r\n#>   sale_id sale_date \r\n#>   <chr>   <date>    \r\n#> 1 S0      2013-02-20\r\n#> 2 S1      2014-05-01\r\n#> 3 S2      2014-05-01\r\n#> 4 S3      2014-06-15\r\n#> 5 S4      2014-07-01\r\n#> 6 S5      2014-12-31\r\ncommercials\r\n#> # A tibble: 5 x 2\r\n#>   comm_id comm_date \r\n#>   <chr>   <date>    \r\n#> 1 C1      2014-01-01\r\n#> 2 C2      2014-04-01\r\n#> 3 C3      2014-07-01\r\n#> 4 C4      2014-09-15\r\n#> 5 C5      2014-09-15\r\n\r\n# Rolling join:\r\n# \"Find the most recent commercial that aired just before this sale\"\r\nleft_join(sales, commercials, by = join_by(max(sale_date >= comm_date)))\r\n#> # ## Automatic pagination
users <- gh("/users", .limit = 50)

if (FALSE) {
## Access developer preview of Licenses API (in preview as of 2015-09-24)
gh("/licenses") # used to error code 415
gh("/licenses", .accept = "application/vnd.github.drax-preview+json")
}
if (FALSE) {
## Access Github Enterprise API
## Use GITHUB_API_URL environment variable to change the default.
gh("/user/repos", type = "public", .api_url = "https://github.foobar.edu/api/v3")
}
if (FALSE) {
## Use I() to force body part to be sent as an array, even if length 1
## This works whether assignees has length 1 or > 1
assignees <- "gh_user"
assignees <- c("gh_user1", "gh_user2")
gh("PATCH /repos/OWNER/REPO/issues/1", assignees = I(assignees))
}
if (FALSE) {
## There are two ways to send JSON data. One is that you supply one or
## more objects that will be converted to JSON automatically via
## jsonlite::toJSON(). In this case sometimes you need to use
## jsonlite::unbox() because fromJSON() creates lists from scalar vectors
## by default. The Content-Type header is automatically added in this
## case. For example this request turns on GitHub Pages, using this
## API: https://docs.github.com/v3/repos/pages/#enable-a-pages-site

gh::gh(
  "POST /repos/{owner}/{repo}/pages",
  owner = "gaborcsardi",
  repo = "playground",
  source = list(
    branch = jsonlite::unbox("master"),
    path = jsonlite::unbox("/docs")
  ),
  .send_headers = c(Accept = "application/vnd.github.switcheroo-preview+json")
)

## The second way is to handle the JSON encoding manually, and supply it
## as a raw vector in an unnamed argument, and also a Content-Type header:

body <- '{ "source": { "branch": "master", "path": "/docs" } }'
gh::gh(
  "POST /repos/{owner}/{repo}/pages",
  owner = "gaborcsardi",
  repo = "playground",
  charToRaw(body),
  .send_headers = c(
    Accept = "application/vnd.github.switcheroo-preview+json",
    "Content-Type" = "application/json"
  )
)
}
